review.title: Multivariate Time Series Classification Using Dynamic Time Warping Template Selection for Human Activity Recognition
review.abstract: Accurate and computationally efficient means for classifying human activities have been the subject of extensive research efforts. Most current research focuses on extracting complex features to achieve high classification accuracy. We propose a template selection approach based on Dynamic Time Warping, such that complex feature extraction and domain knowledge is avoided. We demonstrate the predictive capability of the algorithm on both simulated and real smartphone data.

sections.heading: A. Overview
sections.text: As described in Section II, the standard approach to HAR classification first extracts features from the motion data time series and then classifies them using well-established algorithms. Working with the raw data in the time domain is preferable if it is sufficiently able to capture information about the data. We propose a method based on DTWsubseq and hierarchical clustering that avoids intensive feature extraction and can alleviate many of the feature extraction problems discussed in Section II. Our approach to classification is to use the training data to create time series templates that represent each activity, and then to classify the test data by means of DTWsubseqD based on their similarity to these templates. This type of template-based method is robust to speed and style variations in subjects "movements and potentially requires less training data than function-based methods [8] before we present a general template to complete the classification.

sections.heading: C. Build Templates
sections.text: We consider two methods for selecting templates: DTW Pointwise Averaging (DPA) and DTW Barycenter Averaging (DBA). We provide the algorithm for DPA in algorithm 4 and brief descriptions of DBA.DPA is a simple method for calculating the average of a series of time series. The algorithm first finds the point with minimum distance to all other time series, aligns each time series to that point and finally computes a pointwise average. DBA is a global method that calculates an average series that minimizes the sum of square DTW distances to all rows in the cluster. In each iteration of the algorithm, 1) Run DTW between the average row and each row in the cluster, and extract the associations between the coordinates of the pair.

sections.heading: D. Classify
sections.text: For each training and test sample, we first calculate DTWsubseqD for each template. This returns a distance vector corresponding to the number of templates for each sample. We treat this distance vector as a feature vector and continue by running a dimensionality reduction algorithm (such as PCA) and a classifier (such as SVM) on the DTWsubseqD vectors.

sections.heading: A. UCI HAR Data
sections.text: The data set contains a total of 10,299 samples from 30 subjects who performed six activities in a laboratory: 3 dynamic activities (walking, climbing stairs, going down stairs) and 3 static activities (sitting, standing, lying down). We used 7,352 samples for training and the remaining 2,947 samples for testing.Each measurement (time series) is six-dimensional with dimensions corresponding to acceleration (in ms − 2) and angular velocity (in s − 1) in the x-y-z axis. Acceleration range is [− 1, 1] and angular velocity range is [− 3, 3]. This data set is already pre-processed as provided by the application of noise filters and then scanned in fixed width sliding windows with 50% overlap (128 readings / windows).

sections.text: In this section, we present the results of the UCI-HAR dataset and synthetic data. We examine templates generated by our method and also examine the benefits of using different values of the intersection parameter at the cluster stage. We draw templates that correspond to different clusters of the same activity to demonstrate the performance of our cluster and template construction methods. Templates are shown in Figure 6 and 7 for both DBA and DPA for the UCI dataset and synthetic datasets. Classification accuracy is shown in Tables I and II. sections.heading: C. Synthetic Data
sections.text: Our synthetic data experiments reflect the satisfactory performance of our methods in the case of noisy data and new subjects that are not present in the training phase. Comparing the construction of templates, Figure 7 shows that templates created with DBA are significantly more robust against sporadic noise than those created with DPA. Samples in Figure 7 are created from a single time series and modified by adding noise in a small region of the curve. DBA takes this into account successfully because its template is identical with all curves at points other than the noisy region and its shape is fairly similar to the noisy region. On the other hand, DPA does not manage to capture the identical shape of the curve because it underestimates the magnitudes of the peaks and depths. Since the test data is constructed from a different template (simulating another person), DBA overlaps the training data. All methods with DPA work similarly or better than DBA.

sections.heading: D. Summary of Results
sections.text: We summarize the accuracy results obtained with our algorithm for clarification in Table V. We see that the accuracy of our algorithm is comparable to that of extractions and in most cases performs better.

sections.heading: IX. CONCLUSION
sections.text: In this paper, we presented modifications of the DTW as a more accurate time series similarity measurement and a template-based approach to human activity detection. By experimenting with real data and synthetic data, we show that our approach provides comparable and sometimes even better classification accuracy than the most common method of feature extraction. Compared to feature extraction on real data, our approach has comparable overall test accuracy and better accuracy within activities in the dynamic category. In the case of synthetic data, it achieved higher accuracy in terms of noise robustness and the ability to classify data from new subjects. This is a particularly useful feature for the practical implementation of such classification algorithms, such as on a smartphone app. In addition, the application of our approach goes beyond HAR as long as the dataset meets our definition of multidimensional time series. Since the template approach allows us to extract characteristics without domain knowledge, it can be applied to new datasets without being applied to new datasets.

sections.heading: X. FUTURE WORK
sections.text: We plan to improve our activity detection and template usage in several ways. Possible directions include: modifying DTW to learn more complex activities; cross-validating parameters in hierarchical clusters and DTW such as intersection or bandwidth to increase predictive accuracy; removing redundant templates and limiting overmatch; and creating synthetic data from templates that increase predictive power or can be used instead of real-world data. As the work presented in this paper is not specific to HAR applications, we also plan to apply and evaluate our algorithm to sequential data in other areas of research.
